topics.title: Blood-Brain Barrier Crossing Technologies
subtopics: Focused ultrasound + microbubbles (FUS-BBBO)
Receptor-mediated transcytosis (transferrin receptor, LRP1, insulin receptor)
Nanoparticle carriers: lipid nanoparticles, polymeric NPs, dendrimers, exosomes
Engineered AAVs for CNS delivery (AAV9, AAVrh10, PHP.eB, PHP.eB variants)
Cell-penetrating peptides and shuttle peptides
Nose-to-brain delivery pathways
Intrathecal and intracerebroventricular delivery
BBB-on-a-chip and organ-on-chip screening models
Trojan horse antibody strategies (bispecific antibodies)
Convection-enhanced delivery (CED)
Clinical trials landscape: Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, glioblastoma, lysosomal storage diseases
BBB physiology: tight junctions, pericytes, astrocyte end-feet, efflux transporters
topics.source_guidance: Focus on peer-reviewed research, Nature/Science reviews, clinical trial reports. Key journals: Journal of Controlled Release, Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews, Brain. Include both foundational BBB biology and cutting-edge delivery tech. Look for Denali Therapeutics, Roche Brain Shuttle, InSightec FUS work.
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the biology of the blood-brain barrier: tight junctions, transport mechanisms, why it exists, and how diseases compromise it. Include the history of BBB discovery. Expertise level: Advanced.

Focus exclusively on non-invasive BBB crossing strategies: focused ultrasound, receptor-mediated transcytosis, engineered viruses, and nanoparticles. Compare efficacy, safety profiles, and clinical progress. Expertise level: Expert.

Focus on clinical applications and trials: which BBB-crossing technologies are closest to patients, for which diseases, and what are the remaining obstacles. Cover Alzheimer's, brain tumors, lysosomal storage diseases, and gene therapy delivery to the CNS.

topics.title: CRISPR 2.0: Base Editing, Prime Editing, and Epigenetic Control
topics.notebook_name: CRISPR 2.0: Base Editing, Prime Editing, and Epigenetic Control
subtopics: Base editing: cytosine base editors (CBEs), adenine base editors (ABEs), mechanism and limitations
Prime editing: mechanism (pegRNA + Cas9 nickase + reverse transcriptase), efficiency improvements
Epigenetic editing: CRISPRoff, CRISPRon, dCas9-DNMT3A/TET1 fusions
Delivery bottlenecks: LNPs vs AAVs vs VLPs vs ribonucleoproteins
In vivo vs ex vivo editing tradeoffs
Off-target effects: detection methods (GUIDE-seq, CIRCLE-seq, DISCOVER-seq)
Landmark clinical results: sickle cell (Casgevy), TTR amyloidosis (Verve), liver targets
Next-gen CRISPR: Cas12, Cas13 (RNA targeting), CasX, smaller Cas variants
Regulatory landscape and ethics of germline editing
Agricultural CRISPR applications
topics.source_guidance: Key sources: David Liu lab papers (base/prime editing), Feng Zhang lab, Jennifer Doudna, Beam Therapeutics, Prime Medicine, Verve Therapeutics publications. Nature Biotechnology reviews, NEJM clinical trial reports. Include the Casgevy (exa-cel) approval story.
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the evolution from CRISPR-Cas9 to base editing and prime editing. Explain the molecular mechanisms in detail, their advantages over traditional CRISPR cuts, and current efficiency limitations. Expertise level: Expert.

Focus on epigenetic editing with CRISPR: how CRISPRoff/CRISPRon work, the concept of gene silencing without DNA cuts, therapeutic applications, and why this might be safer than permanent genome edits. Include recent results.

Focus on the clinical translation of precision editing: Casgevy approval, Verve's in vivo base editing for heart disease, delivery challenges, and what the next 5 years of CRISPR medicine look like. Expertise level: Advanced.

topics.title: Japanese History: Culture, Power, and Transformation
topics.notebook_name: Japanese History: Culture, Power, and Transformation
subtopics: Jomon and Yayoi periods: origins of Japanese civilization
Heian court culture: Tale of Genji, aristocratic aesthetics, women writers
Rise of the samurai: Kamakura shogunate, bushido, feudal Japan
Mongol invasions and the kamikaze legend
Muromachi period: Zen Buddhism, tea ceremony, Noh theater, wabi-sabi
Sengoku (Warring States): Oda Nobunaga, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, Tokugawa Ieyasu
Edo period: sakoku (isolation), urbanization, Kabuki, ukiyo-e, merchant culture
Meiji Restoration: rapid modernization, Westernization vs tradition
Imperial Japan: militarism, colonialism, Pacific War
Postwar transformation: occupation, economic miracle, cultural exports
Japanese aesthetics: mono no aware, wabi-sabi, ma (negative space), ikigai
topics.source_guidance: Use broad historical surveys (Cambridge History of Japan, Totman, Jansen), cultural studies, primary source translations. Mix political/military history with cultural/aesthetic history. Include women's history (Murasaki Shikibu, Sei Shonagon). Get contemporary Japan too (Lost Decade, anime/manga cultural export).
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the aesthetic and cultural foundations of Japan: Heian court culture, Zen influence, wabi-sabi, mono no aware, the tea ceremony as philosophy. How did Japan develop such a distinctive aesthetic sensibility? Expertise level: Advanced.

Focus on the political transformations: from imperial court to samurai rule to Tokugawa isolation to Meiji modernization. What made Japan uniquely able to modernize so rapidly? Compare with China and Korea's paths.

Focus on the Edo period as a laboratory of urbanization and culture without industrialization: 250 years of peace, the world's largest city (Edo/Tokyo), merchant culture, woodblock prints, theater, and how isolation bred innovation.

topics.title: Neuroscience of Consciousness and Perception
subtopics: Neural correlates of consciousness (NCC): empirical findings, lesion studies, anesthesia research
Integrated Information Theory (IIT): Tononi's phi, axioms, mathematical framework, criticisms
Global Neuronal Workspace Theory (GNWT): Dehaene and Changeux, ignition, broadcasting
Predictive processing / Bayesian brain: Karl Friston's free energy principle, prediction error minimization
The binding problem: how distributed processing creates unified experience
Default mode network: resting state, mind-wandering, self-referential processing
Psychedelics and neuroplasticity: psilocybin, LSD effects on serotonin 5-HT2A, REBUS model (relaxed beliefs under psychedelics)
Brain-computer interfaces: current state (BrainGate, Neuralink, Stentrode), signal decoding
Attention mechanisms: selective attention, biased competition, attentional blink
Disorders of consciousness: coma, vegetative state, minimally conscious state, locked-in syndrome
Neuroimaging methods: fMRI, EEG, MEG, optogenetics - what each reveals and its limits
topics.source_guidance: ONLY rigorous peer-reviewed neuroscience. Key authors: Giulio Tononi, Stanislas Dehaene, Karl Friston, Anil Seth, Christof Koch. Key journals: Nature Neuroscience, Neuron, PNAS, Trends in Cognitive Sciences. NO philosophy of mind speculation without empirical grounding. Include meta-analyses and systematic reviews where available. The Adversarial Collaboration on consciousness (Templeton Foundation) is a great source.
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the two leading scientific theories of consciousness: Integrated Information Theory and Global Neuronal Workspace Theory. Present the empirical evidence for and against each, including the Templeton Foundation adversarial collaboration results. NO speculation, only data. Expertise level: Expert.

Focus on the predictive brain: Karl Friston's free energy principle, predictive processing, and how the brain constructs perception from predictions rather than raw input. Include Bayesian inference, prediction error, and clinical implications (autism, schizophrenia as prediction errors). Expertise level: Expert.

Focus on psychedelics and neuroscience: the REBUS model, serotonin 5-HT2A receptor mechanisms, what fMRI/EEG show during psychedelic states, entropic brain hypothesis, and clinical trial results for depression and PTSD. Only peer-reviewed evidence.

topics.title: Architecture Beyond Postmodernism: Parametric, Computational, and Sustainable Design
topics.notebook_name: Architecture Beyond Postmodernism: Parametric, Computational, and Sustainable Design
subtopics: Parametricism: Zaha Hadid, Patrik Schumacher, fluid forms, algorithmic generation
Computational design: Grasshopper/Rhino, topology optimization, generative algorithms
Biomimetic architecture: structures inspired by nature, Achim Menges, ICD Stuttgart
Mass timber revolution: CLT, glulam, Brock Commons, tall wood buildings
Responsive and kinetic architecture: Al Bahar Towers, Media-TIC, adaptive facades
3D-printed buildings: ICON, Apis Cor, concrete printing, Mars habitat prototypes
AI in architecture: generative design, Midjourney/DALL-E for concept, text-to-architecture
Sustainable and circular design: Passivhaus, net-zero, cradle-to-cradle, embodied carbon
Deconstructivism legacy: Gehry, Libeskind, Coop Himmelb(l)au, and the transition to digital
BIG (Bjarke Ingels Group): hedonistic sustainability, pragmatic utopia
The starchitect debate: spectacle vs social responsibility
topics.source_guidance: Architectural Record, Dezeen, The Architectural Review, AD (Architectural Design) journal. Patrik Schumacher's manifestos, BIG's 'Yes is More', Achim Menges research. Include both theoretical writings and built project case studies. Photograph-rich sources preferred for the study hub article.
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the rise of parametric design: how computer algorithms changed architecture from drawing to scripting. Cover Zaha Hadid's legacy, Patrik Schumacher's parametricism manifesto, and specific built projects. How does algorithmic form differ from traditional design? Expertise level: Advanced.

Focus on sustainable and biomimetic architecture: mass timber, 3D printing, nature-inspired structures, and how architecture is responding to the climate crisis. Include specific projects and quantified environmental benefits.

Focus on AI and the future of architecture: generative design, text-to-architecture tools, robotic construction, and whether architects will be replaced or augmented. Include the debate about authorship and creativity in algorithmic design.
topics.special_task: ALSO generate a full study hub article (3000-5000 words) with embedded images covering the trajectory from deconstructivism through parametricism to AI-assisted design. Use Wikipedia Commons and architecture photography URLs.

topics.title: The Microbiome and Gut-Brain Axis
subtopics: Gut microbiome composition: phyla, diversity metrics, enterotypes
Gut-brain signaling: vagus nerve, microbial metabolites (SCFAs, tryptophan), immune pathways
Microbiome and mental health: depression, anxiety, autism spectrum - evidence and limitations
Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT): C. diff, IBD, and experimental applications
Probiotics evidence base: what works, what doesn't, strain specificity, prebiotics vs probiotics
Microbiome and aging: diversity loss, inflammaging, centenarian microbiomes
Diet-microbiome interactions: fiber, fermented foods, Mediterranean diet, ultra-processed food effects
Skin microbiome: barrier function, eczema, acne
Oral microbiome and systemic disease: periodontal disease, cardiovascular links
Microbiome in drug metabolism: pharmacomicrobiomics
Human Microbiome Project findings and methodology
topics.source_guidance: Cell, Nature, Science microbiome papers. Key labs: Rob Knight (UCSD), Tim Spector, Jack Gilbert. Human Microbiome Project publications. Be careful to distinguish strong evidence (C. diff FMT) from preliminary findings (depression). Include systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the gut-brain axis: how gut bacteria communicate with the brain via the vagus nerve, metabolites, and immune signaling. What does the evidence actually show about depression, anxiety, and cognition? Be rigorous about what's proven vs preliminary. Expertise level: Advanced.
Focus on practical microbiome science: diet effects, probiotics evidence, FMT for C. diff and beyond, and what individuals can actually do based on current evidence. Separate hype from science.

Focus on the microbiome in aging and longevity: how diversity changes with age, centenarian microbiome studies, inflammaging, and whether microbiome interventions could extend healthspan. Connect to metabolic health.

topics.title: Senolytics and Cellular Senescence
subtopics: Cellular senescence biology: replicative vs stress-induced, p16INK4a, p21, telomere shortening
Senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP): inflammatory cytokines, tissue dysfunction
Senolytic drugs: dasatinib + quercetin (D+Q), navitoclax, fisetin, UBX0101
Senomorphics: rapamycin, metformin, SASP modulators
CAR-T approaches to senescent cells: targeting uPAR, GPNMB
Tissue-specific senescence: brain (astrocytes, microglia), vascular, immune, adipose
Clinical trials landscape: Unity Biotechnology, Oisin Biotechnologies, Mayo Clinic studies
Biomarkers of senescence: SA-beta-gal, p16 expression, SASP factors, senescence scores
Senescence in development and wound healing: beneficial roles
The threshold hypothesis: when does senescent cell burden become pathological?
Connections to other hallmarks of aging: telomere attrition, mitochondrial dysfunction, epigenetic alterations
topics.source_guidance: Key researchers: James Kirkland (Mayo), Judith Campisi (legacy), Jan van Deursen. Key papers: Baker et al. 2011 (INK-ATTAC), Xu et al. 2018 (D+Q in humans). Nature Aging, Aging Cell, Cell Metabolism. Include both the promise and the failures (Unity Biotech Phase 2 failure).
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on the biology of cellular senescence: what triggers it, the SASP, why it evolved (tumor suppression vs aging tradeoff), and how senescent cells accumulate with age. Include the landmark mouse studies that proved clearing senescent cells extends healthspan. Expertise level: Expert.

Focus on senolytic and senomorphic interventions: dasatinib+quercetin, fisetin, navitoclax, rapamycin. Compare mechanisms, clinical evidence, and which are closest to approved therapies. Include both successes and failures honestly.

Focus on next-generation approaches: CAR-T for senescent cells, gene therapy approaches, targeted senolysis, and the senescence biomarker problem. How do you measure if senolytics are working in humans?

topics.title: Philosophy of Technology and AI Ethics
topics.notebook_name: Philosophy of Technology and AI Ethics
subtopics: Heidegger's question concerning technology: Gestell (enframing), technology as revealing
Attention economy: persuasive design, Tristan Harris, behavioral manipulation at scale
AI alignment problem: instrumental convergence, orthogonality thesis, reward hacking
Surveillance capitalism: Shoshana Zuboff's framework, behavioral surplus, prediction products
Post-humanism and transhumanism: Nick Bostrom, enhancement ethics, morphological freedom
Philosophy of AI consciousness: hard problem, Chinese room, zombie arguments, substrate independence
Algorithmic bias and fairness: hiring algorithms, criminal justice, healthcare disparities
Autonomy and manipulation: dark patterns, recommendation engines, epistemic autonomy
Technology and democracy: filter bubbles, deepfakes, platform power, epistemic commons
Ethics of autonomous weapons and lethal autonomous systems (LAWS)
Digital rights and data sovereignty
topics.source_guidance: Mix classic philosophy of technology (Heidegger, Ellul, Mumford) with contemporary work (Zuboff, Crawford, Floridi, Russell). Include empirical studies on tech effects, not just philosophical speculation. Key books: Surveillance Capitalism (Zuboff), Weapons of Math Destruction (O'Neil), Human Compatible (Russell), Atlas of AI (Crawford).
deep_dive_prompts: Focus on surveillance capitalism: Zuboff's framework, how behavioral data extraction works, prediction markets, and the political economy of data. Connect to Heidegger's concept of technology as 'enframing'. Expertise level: Advanced.

Focus on the AI alignment problem: what it means technically, instrumental convergence, the control problem, and current approaches to alignment research. Include both existential risk perspectives and near-term bias/fairness concerns.

Focus on technology and human autonomy: attention economy, persuasive design, algorithmic curation, dark patterns, and what it means for free will and democratic self-governance. Include empirical evidence on behavioral effects.
